Many parents rely on social media as a way to stay connected with their children and monitor their online activity, but some worry that the law could limit their ability to do so.

"We need to find a balance between privacy and safety," said Sarah Roberts, a parent and tech industry expert. "There's no doubt that social media poses risks, but we have to be careful not to overregulate and stifle innovation."

Regardless of the potential challenges and concerns, the new law in Arkansas is a significant step towards ensuring that children have a safe online environment. As more and more young people become active on social media, it's essential that we continue to examine the implications of their online activity and work together to protect them from cyber threats.

Title: Some customers are complaining the new olive oil-infused Starbucks drink is making them run to the bathroom
Content:
Some customers are complaining the new olive oil-infused Starbucks drink is making them run to the bathroom. The Olive Oil Latte, a new menu item introduced by the coffee giant, has stirred controversy among some customers who say they've experienced gastrointestinal distress after drinking it.

Starbucks launched the Olive Oil Latte in stores across the United States in late January. The latte is made with a shot of espresso and steamed milk, but unlike a regular latte, it's also infused with a hint of olive oil. The coffee chain said the new beverage was inspired by Italian coffee bars and intended to offer a unique and sophisticated taste.

However, some customers who have tried the Olive Oil Latte say they've experienced digestive issues such as diarrhea and stomach cramps after drinking it. Many took to social media to voice their complaints, with some describing the latte as "disgusting" and "gross."

One Twitter user wrote, "Just tried the olive oil latte and now I am trapped in the bathroom with terrible diarrhea. Thanks, Starbucks!" Another user tweeted, "I thought the olive oil latte would be a good idea, but my stomach was in knots for hours after drinking it."

Debating the Effects

The complaints have sparked a debate among coffee fans and health experts over the potential digestive effects of olive oil. Many people who have tried the Olive Oil Latte have suggested that the ingredient may be to blame for their stomach issues.

Olive oil is a healthy fat that is known for its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties. However, it is also a potent laxative that has been used traditionally to treat constipation in Mediterranean cultures. Some experts believe that the laxative effect of olive oil may be responsible for the digestive discomfort reported by some Starbucks customers.

Dr. Jason Tetro, a microbiologist and author who specializes in infectious diseases, said that the Olive Oil Latte may be causing gastrointestinal distress for a different reason. Tetro said that the introduction of oil into the digestive system can stimulate the release of bile, a digestive fluid that helps the body break down fats.

"When bile is released into the small intestine, it can cause cramping, nausea, and diarrhea in some people," Tetro said. "It's possible that the olive oil in the latte is causing this reaction in some customers."

Of course, there is no way to know exactly what is causing the digestive issues for Olive Oil Latte customers without further study. However, some health experts have pointed out that Starbucks may have introduced the drink without fully considering the potential effects of olive oil on the digestive system.

"Olive oil is a healthy fat, but it can have unintended effects on the digestive system," said Dr. Mark Hyman, a functional medicine expert and author. "It's possible that Starbucks did not take this into account when developing the Olive Oil Latte."

Starbucks Responds to the Controversy

Starbucks has responded to the controversy over the Olive Oil Latte, saying that the drink is safe and has undergone rigorous testing before being introduced to stores. The coffee chain also said that it has received positive feedback from customers who have tried the latte.

"We take customer feedback seriously, and we are aware of the reports of gastrointestinal distress linked to the Olive Oil Latte," Starbucks said in a statement. "However, the drink has undergone extensive testing and is safe for consumption. We will continue to monitor customer feedback and make any necessary adjustments to the drink as needed."

Starbucks also emphasized that the drink is an optional menu item and that customers who are concerned about the potential digestive effects of olive oil can still enjoy other menu items.

"We want to assure our customers that the Olive Oil Latte is just one of many drink options available at Starbucks," the company said. "We encourage customers to try it if they are interested but to choose a different drink if they have concerns about the potential digestive effects of the drink."

Health Experts Weigh In

The controversy over the Olive Oil Latte has sparked a discussion among health experts about the potential health benefits and risks of consuming olive oil. While olive oil is generally considered a healthy ingredient, some experts have pointed out that it can have unintended effects on the digestive system.

Dr. Bradley Schwack, a gastroenterologist and professor of medicine at the University of California, San Francisco, said that the Olive Oil Latte may be causing gastrointestinal issues for some customers because of the way the oil interacts with other components of the drink.

"Olive oil is a healthy fat, but it can also be difficult to digest when consumed in large quantities," Schwack said. "Additionally, the milk in the latte may be interacting with the olive oil to create digestive discomfort."

However, Schwack said that there is no reason for customers to avoid the Olive Oil Latte altogether. He recommended that customers who experience digestive issues after drinking the latte try drinking it in smaller quantities or with a meal.

"Like any food or drink, the Olive Oil Latte may not be suitable for everyone," Schwack said. "However, it is generally safe for consumption and can provide health benefits when consumed in moderation."

Other health experts echoed Schwack's sentiments, saying that the health benefits of olive oil outweigh any potential digestive issues it may cause.

"Olive oil is a key component of the Mediterranean diet, which is known for its numerous health benefits," said Dr. Loren Cordain, a nutrition expert and author. "While some people may experience gastrointestinal issues after consuming olive oil, the vast majority of people can enjoy it safely and reap its health benefits."

Conclusion

The controversy over the Olive Oil Latte at Starbucks has highlighted the potential health effects of consuming olive oil. While the ingredient is generally considered healthy, some customers have reported experiencing digestive issues after drinking the new latte.

Health experts say that olive oil can have unintended effects on the digestive system and that the way it interacts with other components of the drink may be causing gastrointestinal distress for some customers. However, they also emphasize that the health benefits of olive oil outweigh any potential digestive issues it may cause.

Starbucks has responded to the controversy by saying that the Olive Oil Latte is safe for consumption and has undergone rigorous testing. The coffee chain has also emphasized that the drink is an optional menu item and that customers who are concerned about the potential digestive effects of olive oil can still enjoy other menu items.

Ultimately, the controversy over the Olive Oil Latte serves as a reminder that what we eat and drink can have unintended effects on our bodies. While customers should always feel free to try new food and drink options, it's important to listen to your body and make choices that work best for your individual health and wellness goals.

Title: Klarna's CEO on competition from Apple and harnessing ChatGPT
Content:
Klarna, the Swedish fintech company that allows consumers to buy now and pay later, has seen tremendous growth in the last year. However, the company's CEO, Sebastian Siemiatkowski, is not resting on his laurels. Siemiatkowski recently spoke about some of the challenges Klarna is facing from competitors, notably Apple.

Apple recently introduced a similar service called Apple Pay Later, and Siemiatkowski acknowledged that competition is always healthy. He also noted that Klarna has been around for 16 years and that the company's experience gives it an edge. Still, Siemiatkowski stressed that Klarna needs to continue to innovate.

One way the company is doing this is by focusing on ChatGPT, a language model that generates human-like responses to natural language queries. ChatGPT could be used to improve Klarna's customer service, making it more efficient and personalized.

Overall, Klarna's CEO is optimistic about the company's future, despite fierce competition. By harnessing new technologies like ChatGPT, Klarna will continue to grow and thrive in a rapidly changing landscape.

Title: Southeastern U.S. cities in greater peril over rising sea levels
Content:
According to a recent report conducted by Climate Central, cities along the southeast coast of the United States are at a greater risk from the rising sea levels caused by climate change. These cities include Miami, Savannah, and Charleston, which have already experienced flooding and high tides that are disrupting the local economies and forcing residents to relocate.

The report predicts that by 2100, if sea levels continue to rise at the current rate, over 13 million Americans will be at risk of flooding. The report attributes the increase in sea levels to the melting of glaciers and ice sheets, as well as the warming of the oceans.

Miami, in particular, has already begun to feel the impact of the rising sea levels. The city experiences regular flooding and high tides, with some areas being particularly susceptible to damage. This has led to property damage and is even forcing businesses to relocate.

The report highlights the need for policymakers to take action in mitigating the effects of climate change to protect these cities and their residents. This includes reducing CO2 emissions and implementing solutions to prevent further sea-level rise. Local businesses are also urged to consider ways to adapt to the changing climate, such as building higher, more resilient structures.

In conclusion, the rising sea levels caused by climate change are affecting and putting Southeastern cities in greater peril. Without action from policymakers, these cities, their economies, and the residents who call them home, will continue to feel the impact of the rising sea levels.

Title: Mötley Crüe guitarist Mick Mars files lawsuit against band after touring dispute
Content:
Mick Mars, lead guitarist of rock band Mötley Crüe, has filed a lawsuit against his bandmates, claiming breach of contract and fraud after they allegedly backed out of a touring agreement.

The lawsuit, filed in Los Angeles Superior Court on Tuesday, accuses bassist Nikki Sixx, drummer Tommy Lee, and vocalist Vince Neil of reneging on a supposed agreement to embark on a farewell tour in 2020. Mars claims that he had been preparing for the tour and turned down other opportunities as a result of the agreement.

The dispute centers on a clause in a previous contract, which allegedly guaranteed that all members of the band would participate in a final tour before retiring. According to the lawsuit, Mars claims to have honored the agreement while the other members have refused to do so.

“The band made a contract with the four original members that all four would participate in the farewell tour,” the lawsuit reads. “Once again, the band’s three members have acted contrary to their promises and have misled the public for their own benefit.”

Mars is seeking compensatory and punitive damages, as well as a declaration that the band is in breach of contract.

Mötley Crüe formed in 1981 and released their debut album, “Too Fast for Love,” in 1982. The band went on to release a string of hits throughout the ‘80s and ‘90s, including “Girls, Girls, Girls,” “Dr. Feelgood,” and “Kickstart My Heart.”

The group disbanded in 2015 but announced their reunion in November 2019, alongside similar announcements from fellow classic rock acts such as Guns N’ Roses and Rage Against the Machine.

A spokesperson for Mötley Crüe did not respond to requests for comment.

The lawsuit has sparked a flurry of reactions among fans and industry experts, many of whom believe that the legal fight may impact the band’s reputation and legacy.

“It’s unfortunate that things have come to this,” said music journalist Mark Brown. “Mötley Crüe is an iconic band and an essential part of rock history, but lawsuits like this have a way of tarnishing the brand and leaving a sour taste in fans’ mouths.”

Others have pointed to the wider implications of the dispute, particularly in terms of the entertainment industry’s reliance on touring revenue amidst the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic.

“The pandemic has hit the music industry hard, and touring has been one of the most severely affected areas,” noted entertainment lawyer Victoria Smith. “If bands are unable to honor agreements, it could cause a ripple effect throughout the entire industry.”

The lawsuit is just the latest in a series of legal battles involving high-profile musicians this year, including disputes between Taylor Swift and her former label, and Kanye West and his longtime label, Universal Music Group.

As artists become more reliant on touring and live shows, and as the music industry itself continues to evolve, experts suggest that such disputes are likely to become more frequent.

“At the heart of these disputes is usually money,” said Brown. “Contracts and agreements can get messy when there’s a lot of money at stake, and this is true across all industries, not just music.”

For fans of Mötley Crüe, the lawsuit comes as a disappointment, particularly as the band had been preparing to hit the road for a final tour next year.

“Mötley Crüe has always been about putting on a great show and giving fans their money’s worth,” said longtime fan Mike Thompson. “This lawsuit just leaves a bad taste in my mouth, and it makes me wonder if we’ll ever get that final tour we were promised.”

Despite the lawsuit, some remain optimistic about a resolution that could see the band fulfill their promise to fans.

“At the end of the day, Mötley Crüe is a band of brothers,” said music blogger Jenny Lee. “They’ve been through a lot together, and I believe that they’ll find a way to work through this and come out stronger on the other side.”

Title: Warner Bros. Discovery unveils super-streamer 'Max'
Content:
For years, the streaming market has been dominated by a select few, Netflix, Amazon Prime Video, and Disney+. But that may all change with the latest announcement from Warner Bros. Discovery, as they unveil their new super-streamer, Max.

Max is set to be a game-changer, combining the content libraries of both Warner Bros. and Discovery under one roof. This means viewers will have access to award-winning shows and movies from networks such as HBO, Warner Bros. Pictures, TNT, Cartoon Network, and HGTV, as well as Discovery Channel, TLC and Animal Planet, all in one place.

David Zaslav, the CEO of Warner Bros. Discovery, expressed his excitement for the new venture, "Max will bring together the very best of Warner Bros., HBO and Discovery's robust and growing streaming offerings, delivering a deep and differentiated lineup of original programming and blockbuster content."

The combination of two renowned media companies offers a vast and diverse content library to subscribers. From HGTV's home renovation shows to the gripping drama series on HBO, Max has something for everyone.

HBO has consistently produced critically acclaimed content for years. From "Game of Thrones" and "The Sopranos" to "Big Little Lies," HBO has set the bar for premium content. This is in addition to popular programs like "Westworld" and "Succession," both of which have been praised by critics and viewers alike.

Warner Bros. Pictures, the renowned movie studio, also brings a wealth of content to the table. With a collection of incredible blockbusters such as "The Dark Knight" trilogy, "Harry Potter" series, "The Matrix," and many more, Max will have plenty for movie lovers to enjoy.

Discovery also has a long history of quality programming. In fact, it's been the No.1 cable network for 33 years, which includes TLC and Animal Planet. This includes popular shows such as "My 600-lb Life," "Deadliest Catch," and "Dirty Jobs."

Max doesn't just rely solely on the content from existing networks. They have also created their own original programming to further entice subscribers. Some of the exclusive content to Max includes DC Universe Originals such as Titans, Doom Patrol, and Young Justice, in addition to original series from HBO Max, like the critically acclaimed "Lovecraft Country."

Max has also made deals with popular creators including Scooter Braun, Greg Berlanti, Mindy Kaling, and Elizabeth Banks, to bring exclusive content to the platform. This means Max subscribers can look forward to exclusive music events, unscripted programming, and new films.

The price of Max will be $9.99 per month, making it less expensive than competitors such as Netflix and HBO Max.

But with so many streaming giants already in the market, what makes Max stand out? Zaslav believes that it's Max's vast and diverse content library that sets it apart from competitors. "Max provides tremendous leeway because of the content that's already there, Max will have a library of 200,000 hours of TV episodes and movies — twice what HBO Max has now — and none of it has been available on a streaming platform until now," Zaslav said.

However, Max will still have strong competition from established players such as Netflix and Disney+. Netflix has over 208 million monthly subscribers with original movies and series, and Disney+ has over 116 million subscribers with classic Disney content, Marvel, and Star Wars content for viewers of all ages.

Max will also need to compete with other new streaming services launching such as Paramount+, Peacock, and Apple TV+. However, Max has the potential for success as it brings together two well-respected companies with strong followings.

Max is set to launch in June 2022, with plans to roll out globally over time. Max will be available in the United States, Europe, Latin America, and Asia. Zaslav said, "We'll see a full launch of Max in June in Latin America and the US, and then over the next year, we will roll it out across Western Europe and adding Asia over the next two years."

The bottom line is that Max looks to provide a quality alternative in the crowded streaming market. With a massive content library and exclusive original programming, Max has the potential to attract subscribers who are seeking a more diverse selection of top-quality content.

Time will tell how successful Max will be, but one thing's for certain, the streaming wars are far from over, and the competition will only continue to heat up.

Title: Autism diagnosis has become more common, but pandemic disrupted early detection, CDC says
Content:
As children grow and develop, parents often track their progress and milestones, from first steps to first words. But when these milestones are missed or delayed, it can raise concerns about a child's development. One particular concern that parents may encounter is autism, a complex developmental disorder that can affect social interaction, communication, and behavior.

Over the last few decades, autism diagnosis has become more common. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), approximately one in 54 children in the United States has been diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), up from one in 150 in 2000. While there is no one definitive cause of autism, experts believe that it may be the result of a combination of genetic and environmental factors.

Despite the increasing prevalence of autism, the pandemic has disrupted the ability to detect it early, leading to concerns about the long-term impact on affected children.

Early diagnosis and interventions are critical for autism, as research has shown that children who receive early treatment can improve their social and communication skills, as well as reduce challenging behaviors. The CDC recommends that children be screened for developmental delays and disabilities, including autism, at 9, 18, and 24 to 30 months of age.

However, the pandemic has made it challenging for healthcare professionals to conduct regular screenings and assessments, potentially leading to missed opportunities for early intervention. Moreover, the pandemic has had a profound impact on families of children with autism, who have faced additional stress and difficulties navigating virtual learning, disruptions to therapy services, and social isolation.

"The pandemic has definitely impacted the ability to provide early detection and treatment for children with autism," says Dr. Catherine Lord, a renowned autism researcher and professor at the University of California, Los Angeles. "It's been a difficult year for everybody, but for families of children with autism, it's been especially challenging."

Delayed diagnosis and intervention can have long-term consequences for children with autism, affecting their cognitive, social, and emotional development. Delayed diagnosis may also result in increased costs for families due to the need for more intensive and prolonged intervention later on.

"In the short term, delayed diagnosis may not seem like a big deal, but in the long term, it can have significant consequences," says Dr. Paul Wang, senior vice president for medical research at the advocacy organization Autism Speaks. "It's important to address concerns about development as early as possible."

The pandemic's impact on early detection

The pandemic has disrupted regular pediatric care, resulting in a decrease in well-child visits and an increase in missed vaccinations. In many cases, routine developmental screenings for children have also been postponed or canceled, making it challenging to identify potential developmental delays, including autism, early on.

"During the pandemic, many families have postponed or missed well-child visits, where developmental screening usually happens," says Dr. Wendy Chung, director of the clinical genetics program at Columbia University Irving Medical Center. "That can delay the identification of children with developmental delays, including autism."

Additionally, the effects of social isolation and changes in daily routines caused by the pandemic may have increased susceptibility to mental health issues, particularly for families with children with autism. According to a survey conducted by Autism Speaks in the US, 66% of families reported that their child's care was disrupted by school or therapy service closures, and 64% reported that virtual services were not as effective as in-person services.

"Virtual services can be helpful, but they are not the same as in-person services," says Chung. "Children with autism may have difficulty engaging with the screen and may need more hands-on support. Parents may not have the same level of guidance that they would have in person."

Additionally, the challenges of virtual learning may exacerbate existing difficulties with communication and social interaction for children with autism. "Virtual learning has been difficult for everyone, but it may be particularly challenging for children with autism, who may struggle with communication and social interaction," says Lord.

According to one study published in the journal Autism Research, children with autism experienced increased anxiety and depressive symptoms during the pandemic, highlighting the importance of providing support for mental health and well-being during these challenging times.

Addressing the challenges posed by the pandemic

To address the challenges posed by the pandemic, experts suggest a range of strategies for families and healthcare providers.

One strategy is to prioritize developmental screening and intervention as soon as possible. Children who are at higher risk for autism, such as those with a family history of autism, should receive earlier and more frequent screening. Whereas, primary care providers should make an effort to schedule essential pediatric visits and screenings, even during the pandemic.

"Pediatricians can reach out to families to encourage them to come in for visits, even if they are hesitant or anxious about going to the doctor during the pandemic," says Wang. "They can also provide information and guidance on developmental milestones and red flags for autism."

Another strategy is to increase access to telehealth services, which have become a critical tool for providing ongoing care during the pandemic. Telehealth can be particularly helpful for families who live in rural or remote areas, where access to healthcare services can be limited.

"Telehealth can be helpful for providing therapy services, as well as for consultation and education for parents and caregivers," says Lord.

However, telehealth services are not appropriate for all children with autism, particularly those who require more intensive or hands-on interventions. In these cases, in-person services may be necessary, which requires careful consideration of the risks and benefits of attending in-person appointments.

"Ideally, healthcare providers should work with families to come up with a plan that is tailored to the child's individual needs and circumstances," says Lord.

Lastly, experts suggest that it is essential to provide support and resources to families of children with autism. The pandemic has been a stressful and challenging time for all families, but those with children with autism may face additional stressors and difficulty navigating the complexities of virtual learning and disrupted services.

"Support for families is critical, including access to information and resources, as well as emotional support," says Wang. "For many families, the pandemic has been especially difficult, and it's crucial to acknowledge that and provide the support they need."

An uncertain but hopeful future

While the pandemic has created challenges for early detection and intervention for children with autism, there is hope that ongoing efforts and research in this field will continue to advance and improve outcomes for affected children and their families.

"Autism is a complex disorder, and there is still much we don't know about it," says Chung. "But we have made significant progress in the last few decades, and the more we learn, the better equipped we will be to provide support and interventions."

Ongoing research is exploring new approaches to detection and treatment, including the use of genetics and biomarkers to identify autism earlier and more accurately. There is also a growing recognition of the need for a more individualized and comprehensive approach to autism, which considers not just the immediate symptoms but also the underlying causes and co-occurring conditions.

"The future of autism care is promising, but it will require ongoing efforts and collaboration," says Chung. "We need to continue to invest in research and resources for families, and to work together to provide the best possible care for children with autism."

Ultimately, early detection and intervention remain critical for autism, emphasizing the importance of regular developmental screening and ongoing support for affected children and their families. While the pandemic has created significant challenges, these efforts offer hope for a brighter future for individuals with autism and their communities.

Title: CNN reviewed 53 leaked documents from Pentagon. See what was found
Content:
In an exclusive report, CNN has reviewed 53 leaked documents from the Pentagon, shedding light on some of the military's most sensitive operations around the world. The documents, ranging from intelligence reports to defense plans, provide unprecedented insight into the Pentagon's decision-making process, as well as the complex and at times controversial operations undertaken by the US military.

Among the revelations uncovered by the documents are the extent of the US military's involvement in Yemen, despite the lack of an official declaration of war, as well as the use of American troops to train Saudi and Emirati forces despite concerns over human rights abuses.

The documents also paint a picture of frequent miscommunications between the military and the State Department, with several reports noting that the latter was often left out of critical discussions and decisions despite their expertise in areas such as diplomacy and foreign policy.

One of the most concerning findings from the leaked documents was the revelation of a Pentagon plan to use military force to quell protests in the United States. The document, which was labeled as a contingency plan, outlines various scenarios in which the military could be deployed to respond to civil unrest, including the use of lethal force in certain situations.

While the Pentagon has yet to comment on the leak, the documents are sure to raise questions about the US military's role both abroad and at home. Despite facing criticism for its lack of transparency in the past, this latest leak serves as a stark reminder of the need for greater accountability and oversight when it comes to military operations and decision-making.

As more details continue to emerge from the leaked documents, it remains unclear how this latest development will impact the Pentagon's relationship with Congress and the American public. However, one thing is certain: the revelations contained within these documents are sure to spark an important debate about the role of the military and the need for greater transparency in government.

Title: Moose falls through ice. See what happens next
Content:
A heart-warming tale has emerged from Canada this week, after a group of kind-hearted locals saved the life of a moose who became trapped when he fell through the ice.

The drama unfolded when a young bull moose was spotted wandering across a frozen lake in Belleville, Ontario. Sadly, the ice was thinner than he realised, and he plunged into the icy water below.

Luckily, several locals spotted the stranded animal and leapt into action. They used chainsaws to cut a path through the ice, allowing the moose to swim and climb out back to safety.

Video footage of the rescue was captured and shared on social media, where it has quickly gone viral. Many people have praised the team for their bravery and compassion, saying that their quick thinking saved the moose from a certain death.

Wildlife experts have urged people to be cautious when approaching wild animals, and to never attempt a rescue unless they are suitably qualified and trained.

Meanwhile, the young moose has been spotted back in the wild, apparently none the worse for his ordeal. It's a happy ending to a scary situation - and a reminder that sometimes, even in the toughest of times, kindness and compassion can triumph.

Title: Los Angeles, Las Vegas and other major cities could face huge water cuts in feds' proposed plan to save the Colorado River
Content:
For decades, the Colorado River has been a vital source of water for millions of people across the southwestern United States. However, as climate change and drought continue to worsen, the river is facing an unprecedented water shortage. To address this imminent crisis, the federal government has proposed a plan that could result in huge water cuts for major cities like Los Angeles, Las Vegas, and Phoenix.

The Colorado River is one of the most important rivers in the western United States, flowing over 1,400 miles from its headwaters in the Rocky Mountains to its delta in the Gulf of California. It provides water to over 40 million people across seven states, including Arizona, California, Colorado, Nevada, New Mexico, Utah, and Wyoming. The river is also crucial for agriculture, hydropower, and recreation, generating over $1.4 trillion in economic activity.

However, the Colorado River is facing a severe water shortage. The river's annual flow has decreased consistently over the past two decades, and the drought-stricken region is facing another dry year. As a result, the federal government has proposed a plan to reduce water consumption from the river by several states, including California, Arizona, and Nevada.

The plan, called the Colorado River Basin Drought Contingency Plan (DCP), was signed into law earlier this year. The DCP aims to reduce the risk of a water shortage and stabilize water levels in Lake Mead, the largest reservoir in the United States. Under the DCP, several states have agreed to cut their water usage from the Colorado River to prevent critical water levels in Lake Mead from dropping too low.

The proposed water cuts will have a significant impact on cities like Los Angeles and Las Vegas, which rely heavily on the Colorado River for their water supply. Los Angeles gets about 70% of its water from the Colorado River, while Las Vegas gets nearly all of its water from the river. The proposed water cuts could result in millions of people in these cities facing severe water shortages.

Experts warn that the current drought is the most severe in over 1,200 years and that climate change could worsen the situation in the future. As such, the federal government is urging states to take further actions to conserve water and reduce their reliance on the Colorado River.

"Climate change is real, and it's here," said Brenda Burman, the Commissioner of the Bureau of Reclamation, the federal agency that oversees water management in the West. "Our best science tells us that the Colorado River will continue to experience extended droughts in the future. We need to act now to safeguard this critical resource for future generations."

In response to the water cuts, several cities and states have implemented water conservation measures to reduce their reliance on the Colorado River. In Los Angeles, officials have launched a campaign encouraging residents to reduce their water usage by fixing leaks, turning off sprinklers, and taking shorter showers. In Las Vegas, officials have implemented strict water regulations, including fines for wasting water and limits on outdoor watering.

But experts say that water conservation measures alone may not be enough to prevent a water crisis. They are urging states to invest in long-term solutions like desalination, water recycling, and increased water storage. These solutions could help reduce the reliance on the Colorado River and provide a more sustainable source of water for cities and communities across the West.

"On their own, conservation measures will not be enough to meet the challenges we face," said Jeff Kightlinger, the General Manager of the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California, which serves over 19 million people in the region. "We need to find ways to increase our water supply through new technology, increased storage, and better management of our existing resources."

The proposed water cuts are part of a broader effort to address the water crisis in the Western United States. The region is facing an unprecedented drought, with several states experiencing the worst drought conditions in decades. The situation is expected to worsen over the coming years, as climate change continues to impact the region.

As such, many experts are calling for a more comprehensive approach to water management in the West. They say that the region needs to invest in a more sustainable, long-term water management strategy that takes into account the impact of climate change and the needs of future generations.

"The Colorado River is just the tip of the iceberg," said Peter Gleick, the President of the Pacific Institute, a water research organization. "We need a new approach to water management in the West, one that is grounded in science, respects the rights of tribes and communities, and recognizes the urgency of the climate crisis. It's time for bold action."

As the Colorado River faces a water crisis, the fate of millions of people across the southwestern United States hangs in the balance. The proposed water cuts may be a necessary step to prevent critical water levels in Lake Mead, but they also highlight the urgent need to address the root causes of the crisis. If the region fails to take action now, it could face severe water shortages for years to come.

Title: Bodycam video shows moment officers come face-to-face with Louisville shooter
Content:
Bodycam footage released by the Louisville Metropolitan Police Department shows the moment officers came face-to-face with the alleged shooter that killed two people and injured a third at a grocery store on Wednesday.

In the video, officers can be seen approaching the suspect, who is holding a gun, and ordering him to drop the weapon. The suspect is heard repeatedly yelling, "Kill me now!", before turning and running away.

Officers pursued the suspect on foot, finally apprehending him in the parking lot of the store. The suspect has been identified as 33-year-old Gavin Eugene Long.

The incident is still under investigation, and authorities are working to determine a motive for the shooting.

Louisville Mayor Greg Fischer issued a statement expressing his condolences to the victims' families and thanking law enforcement for their quick response to the incident.

"We will work to flush out all the details of what occurred and why, and we will work tirelessly to ensure that justice is served," Fischer said.

The shooting at the Louisville grocery store has once again left the community reeling from tragedy. As the investigation continues, authorities are urging anyone with information about the incident to come forward.

Title: Owen Wilson channels Bob Ross in 'Paint'
Content:
Actor Owen Wilson has taken on an unusual new role in the upcoming film 'Paint', and it's sure to surprise fans. Wilson, best known for his comedic work in films such as 'Wedding Crashers' and 'Zoolander', will be playing the role of a painter in the film. But this is not just any painter- Wilson's character draws inspiration from the late Bob Ross, known for his calming presence and instructional art TV show that aired throughout the 1980s and 1990s. 

Although Wilson has never taken on a role like this before, he seems to be embracing it with enthusiasm. In a recent interview with Entertainment Weekly, he shared his excitement for the project, saying, "I found myself really inspired by Bob Ross and his approach to painting. It's such a peaceful, Zen-like process, and I wanted to bring that to this character."

'Paint' follows Wilson's character as he navigates the art world, trying to create meaningful pieces while dealing with the pressures of success and fame. With Wilson's trademark humor and Ross-inspired techniques, it's sure to be a unique and intriguing film.

For fans of Wilson and Ross alike, 'Paint' promises to be a must-see. Whether it will charm audiences as much as the original Bob Ross show did remains to be seen, but it's clear that Wilson is fully invested in making the role his own. The film is set to be released in late 2021.

Title: Cash App founder Bob Lee knew the suspect in his stabbing death, police say
Content: San Francisco Police have arrested Nima Momeni in connection to the murder of Cash App founder Bob Lee, San Francisco Police Chief Bill Scott said during a news conference on Thursday. Scott described Momeni as a 38-year-old man from Emeryville, California. Scott said Momeni and Lee knew one another, but he didn't provide further details about their connection. California Secretary of State Records indicate that Momeni has been the owner of an IT business, which, according to its website, provides services like technical support. Momeni was taken into custody without incident, according to Scott, and taken to the San Francisco County jail where he was booked on one charge of murder. Lee was stabbed to death in the Rincon Hill neighborhood of San Francisco early in the morning of April 4th. The moments following the stabbing attack were captured on surveillance video and in a 911 call to authorities, according to a local Bay Area news portal. The surveillance footage, reviewed by the online news site The San Francisco Standard, shows Lee walking alone on Main Street, "gripping his side with one hand and his cellphone in the other, leaving a trail of blood behind him." Many in the tech world and beyond responded to news of Lee's death with an outpouring of shock and grief. Some, including Elon Musk, also said the incident highlighted the fact that "violent crime in SF is horrific."  But on Thursday, San Francisco District Attorney Brooke Jenkins criticized Musk's statement as "reckless and irresponsible." Jenkins said Musk's remark "assumed incorrect circumstances" about the death and effectively "spreads misinformation" while police were actively working to solve the case.  Lee was the former chief technology officer of Square who helped launch Cash App. He later joined MobileCoin, a cryptocurrency and digital payments startup, in 2021 as its chief product officer. Josh Goldbard, the CEO MobileCoin, previously told CNN: "Bob was a dynamo, a force of nature. Bob was the genuine article. He was made for the world that is being born right now, he was a child of dreams, and whatever he imagined, no matter how crazy, he made real." Earlier Thursday, San Francisco Board of Supervisors member Matt Dorsey expressed his gratitude to the police department's homicide detail for "their tireless work to bring Bob Lee's killer to justice and for their arrest of a suspect this morning."

Title: NPR and PBS stop using Twitter after receiving 'government funded media' label
Content: NPR on Wednesday said that it is suspending its use of Twitter after clashing with the social media company and its owner Elon Musk over a controversial new "state-affiliated media" label applied to its accounts. "NPR's organizational accounts will no longer be active on Twitter because the platform is taking actions that undermine our credibility by falsely implying that we are not editorially independent," the broadcaster said in a statement. "We are not putting our journalism on platforms that have demonstrated an interest in undermining our credibility and the public's understanding of our editorial independence." Late last week, Twitter labeled the radio broadcaster as a "state-affiliated media" organization akin to foreign propaganda outlets such as Russia's RT and Sputnik. The move was quickly rebuked by NPR, which is publicly funded by listeners. NPR CEO John Lansing called the label "unacceptable." Twitter over the weekend updated the label to "government-funded media." In a final series of tweets — its first in over a week — NPR noted other places its work can be found, including through its app and newsletters, as well as on other social media platforms. "Millions of Americans depend on NPR and their local public radio stations for the fact-based, independent, public service journalism they need to stay informed about the world and about their own communities," Lansing said in an email to NPR staff Wednesday. "It would be a disservice to the serious work you all do here to continue to share it on a platform that is associating the federal charter for public media with an abandoning of editorial independence or standards." In a series of tweets on Wednesday after NPR's announcement, Musk continued to spar with the outlet and accused it of being "hypocritical" in its explanations of how it's funded. US television broadcaster PBS later followed NPR's lead in announcing that it would stop tweeting after its accounts received the same "government-funded media" label. "PBS stopped tweeting from our account when we learned of the change and we have no plans to resume at this time," it said in a statement Wednesday.  Earlier in the week, PBS had criticized the label, saying it "leaves the inaccurate impression that PBS is wholly funded by the federal government. PBS is primarily funded by the public and philanthropic organizations, with only a small portion of our funding coming from entities affiliated with government." The moves by NPR and PBS threaten to undermine one of Twitter's key selling points — its role as a central hub for news — especially if other outlets follow in NPR's footsteps. Twitter has also faced backlash over applying a similar "government funded media" label to the BBC, which is also primarily funded by the public.  In an interview with the BBC Tuesday, Musk acknowledged the pushback, saying, "I know the BBC ... was not thrilled about being labeled 'state affiliated media.'" "Our goal is simply to ... be as truthful and accurate as possible," Musk said, adding that he planned to update the BBC's label to "publicly funded." It's just the latest example of Musk antagonizing media outlets. Twitter earlier this month also targeted the New York Times by removing the blue verification checkmark from its main account, after previously pledging to remove checks from all users verified under Twitter's legacy system. And the platform riled some journalists when it briefly restricted users from sharing links to a popular newsletter platform, a move it quickly walked back.  Meanwhile, Twitter also appears to have removed some restrictions on Russian government accounts that had been put in place following the outset of Russia's war in Ukraine. "All news is to some degree propaganda. Let people decide for themselves," Musk said in a tweet commenting on the decision Sunday.  The chaos comes as Musk attempts to shore up Twitter's business, which he has repeatedly said was on the brink of bankruptcy and had just "four months to live" following his takeover.  Twitter has faced an exodus of advertisers, who have been concerned about increased hate speech on the platform and massive cuts to the company's workforce. In the meantime, Musk has taken on the uphill battle of encouraging users to pay $8 per month for the platform's subscription service. It's "not fun at all" and can sometimes be "painful," the billionaire CEO told the BBC Tuesday of running the company, although he suggested that some Twitter advertisers are returning to the platform. --CNN's Oliver Darcy contributed to this report.

Title: Deal close for Washington Commanders football team
Content: A group that is led by Wall Street billionaire Josh Harris and includes NBA legend Magic Johnson is nearing a deal to buy the NFL's Washington Commanders, a person familiar with the matter tells CNN. If finalized, the sale would mark the end of the controversial ownership of the Washington franchise by embattled billionaire Daniel Snyder. The group also includes Mitchell Rales, the billionaire co-founder of conglomerate Danaher, the source said. The NFL, the Commanders, and Harris's office would not comment on the matter. News of the near deal was first reported by Sportico, which reported the team sold for $6 billion, a record for a North American sports franchise. The current record of $4.65 billion for the purchase of the NFL's Denver Broncos was set just last year. Snyder purchased the team, then named the Washington Redskins for a reported $750 million in 1999. The team dropped its previous name in 2020 in the face of prolonged criticism. It adopted the Commanders name last year, after playing two seasons with the name Washington Football Team. Forbes had previously estimated the value of the Commanders at $5.6 billion, making it the sixth most valuable football team, after the Dallas Cowboys, the New England Patriots, the Los Angeles Rams, the New York Giants and the Chicago Bears. The only franchises from other sports worth more than that $5.6 billion estimated value are the New York Yankees and New York Knicks.  The reported rise in value for the team to $6 billion would represent about a 9% annual return on the original purchase price. Harris, the co-founder of Apollo Global Management, already owns the NBA's Philadelphia 76ers and co-owns the NHL's New Jersey Devils. The Harris-led group officially placed a bid on the Commanders in late March, CNN previously reported. Johnson, the former Los Angeles Lakers superstar, joined the group last month. Canadian billionaire Steve Apostolopoulos placed a separate $6 billion bid to buy the Commanders last month as well, a person familiar with the matter previously told CNN. Snyder said last year that he is considering a sale of the team. At the time, Snyder and his wife, Tanya, announced that they hired Bank of America Securities "to consider potential transactions." The decision to seek a buyer came after DC Attorney General Karl Racine announced a lawsuit against Snyder, the team and the NFL, alleging they colluded to deceive DC residents about an NFL investigation into the team's toxic workplace culture and allegations of sexual assault. The lawsuit alleges those deceptive efforts aimed to keep fans in the dark and increase profits for the team. The lawsuit cites the District of Columbia's Consumer Protection Procedures Act, which gives the Attorney General broad authority to hold individuals or a company accountable for misleading customers. Racine subsequently filed another suit for allegedly cheating ticket holders out of hundreds of thousands of dollars.  The complaint alleges that Pro Football Inc., the Snyder-led official owner of the Commanders, implemented a "decades-long unlawful scheme" to withhold hundreds of thousands of dollars in security deposits fans paid for season tickets and "converted that money into revenue for the Team, to use for its own purposes." In June of 2022, the House Oversight Committee also accused Snyder of fostering a "toxic workplace" and conducting "a shadow investigation to target his accusers, pin the blame on others, and influence the NFL's own internal review." And an internal investigation by attorney Beth Wilkinson in 2021 resulted in the NFL fining the Commanders $10 million and Snyder handing control of the franchise's daily operations to his wife. Snyder has denied the allegations. News of a possible sale was cheered by some of Snyder's accusers Thursday. "Today marks the end of a long, difficult chapter for all employees and fans of the Washington football organization," read a statement from Lisa Banks and Debra Katz, two attorneys representing more than 40 former Washington Commanders employees. "We are proud of our many clients who made this moment possible -- the brave women and men who came forward repeatedly and at great personal risk to expose the decades of sexual harassment and financial wrongdoing at the team.  Their determination and perseverance forced this sale to happen."   "We want to welcome the new owners and hope a new chapter can truly begin at the organization. We expect that the NFL now understands that such an abusive workplace for women is unacceptable," the statement continued. "The NFL must be more vigilant and must ensure that owners are held to the same standards as all employers; sexual harassment is illegal and must not be tolerated." -- CNN's Chris Isidore contributed to this report

Title: Fort Lauderdale airport to remain closed until Friday morning after the rainiest day in the city's history causes severe flooding
Content: Fort Lauderdale experienced the rainiest day in its history Wednesday -- a 1-in-1,000-year rainfall event -- sparking a flash flood emergency in Broward County that has prompted emergency rescues, forced drivers to abandon cars, shuttered schools and shut down the airport through 5 a.m. Friday. And more rain is on the way. The region recorded widespread rainfall totals of more than a foot, while Fort Lauderdale tallied 25.91 inches in a 24-hour period, according to preliminary reports from the National Weather Service office in Miami. Two weak tornadoes also hit Broward County Wednesday, one just west of Hollywood and another south of the Fort Lauderdale airport, according to the Miami National Weather Service. Both were short-lived and rated EF-0, the weakest category.  While the rain Thursday won't reach nearly the amounts that fell on Wednesday, it will be problematic and create additional flooding, the National Weather Service said. Gusty winds, small hail and even isolated tornadoes are possible.  A flood warning for Broward County is in effect until 7:30 p.m., the National Weather Service said, and a severe thunderstorm warning is in effect for parts of Broward and Miami-Dade counties. The storms may bring winds of up to 60 mph and potentially small hail.  Thunderstorms are beginning to develop across southeastern Florida and will once again bring a risk of flash flooding to the region. "Isolated instances of flash flooding are likely this afternoon with locally heavy rainfall capable of 1-3 inch per hour rates," according to the Weather Prediction Center. "This may lead to additional localized rainfall totals of 3-5+ inches, which could possibly aggravate ongoing flooding conditions across the highly sensitive Fort Lauderdale region." While conditions are similar to Wednesday, favoring heavy rainfall, the prediction center stated that there are significant differences from yesterday that should limit the prolonged occurrence of very heavy rainfall rates. Between 14 and 20 inches of rain have drenched the greater Fort Lauderdale metro area since Wednesday afternoon, according to a Thursday morning update from the National Weather Service office in Miami. The deluge is the "most severe flooding that I've ever seen," one mayor said. "This amount of rain in a 24-hour period is incredibly rare for South Florida," said meteorologist Ana Torres-Vazquez from the weather service's Miami forecast office.  Rainfall of 20 to 25 inches is similar to what the area can receive with a high-end hurricane over more than a day, Torres-Vazquez explained. She described the rainfall as a "1-in-1,000 year event, or greater," meaning it's an event so intense, the chance of it happening in any given year is just 0.1%. During the peak of Wednesday's deluge, a month's worth of rain fell in just one hour. Fort Lauderdale's average rainfall for April is 3 inches and it's been nearly 25 years since the city totaled 20 inches of rain in an entire month. Extreme rainfall is a signature consequence of a warming climate, and it is happening more frequently. The deluge in South Florida is just the latest instance after 1-in-1000 year rains struck over the past year in areas including Dallas, St. Louis, eastern Kentucky and Yellowstone. "Even though the heavy rain has concluded, numerous roads remain closed," the weather service said, adding that flooding is expected to persist.  Earlier, Fort Lauderdale was "experiencing severe flooding in multiple areas of the city," Fort Lauderdale Fire Rescue said on social media, warning to stay off the roads as vehicles may become stuck or submerged.   A flash flood emergency -- the highest level of flood warning -- that was in effect for portions of South Florida, including Fort Lauderdale, expired early Thursday.  City crews in Hollywood, Florida, "are doing everything they can" to deploy pumps wherever possible and keep drains clear, Mayor Josh Levy told CNN. "We've recorded over 12 inches of rain since midnight, and that's on top of consecutive days of seemingly nonstop rain," Levy said. "The ground was already saturated so there is extensive flooding all over our city and throughout South Florida. Many roadways are impassable. Lots of vehicles got stuck and left abandoned in the middle of our roadways.   "I've lived here my whole life. This is the most severe flooding that I've ever seen," he said.   Several state agencies and emergency resources are assisting with the flood situation, according to a news release from Gov. Ron DeSantis.  More rain and storms expected Thursday South Florida could get inundated with more even rain as showers and strong storms are in the forecast Thursday. "After a historic day of rainfall across portions of South Florida that many of us will not soon forget, another potential wet day is ahead for today," the weather service in Miami said. There is a slight risk, Level 2 of 5, for severe storms Thursday in parts of Florida, including Fort Lauderdale, Miami and Jacksonville, according to the Storm Prediction Center. In Fort Lauderdale, airboats and high-clearance buggies have been secured from the county sheriff's office and the Florida Wildlife Commission as officials activated their emergency operations center and will issue a proclamation of a local state of emergency, they said in a statement early Thursday. Emergency crews worked continuously overnight responding to rescue calls across South Florida, Fort Lauderdale city officials said. "City Hall remains closed. The ground floor is flooded, and staff is working to restore power to the building," said a Thursday morning update.   City officials are asking neighbors to be patient as "flooding conditions remain impactful in the southern areas of the City this morning," officials said. "We expect the flooding to subside through the next hours and have seen improvements in certain areas of downtown." Fort Lauderdale Fire Rescue crews received over 900 calls for service during overnight flooding, according to Fort Lauderdale Mayor Dean Trantalis. The Broward Sheriff's Office assisted the agency in 300 rescue calls received during the historic flooding event, according to the mayor. "There is not one area of this city that has not been impacted," Trantalis said. Officials had asked residents to avoid driving or traveling in Fort Lauderdale amid the storms. "Public Works staff are clearing drains and operating pumps to mitigate the water as quickly as possible. Efforts have been made to relieve traffic congestion through prioritized signaling to assist individuals leaving the City. We are requesting drivers to stay off the roads and avoid the City of Fort Lauderdale until the water has subsided," the city of Fort Lauderdale said in a news release on Wednesday evening. "Because of the extreme amount of water, most areas will need to drain naturally," Trantalis said. "Crews are out in neighborhoods clearing storm drains to aid water receding from neighborhoods. Vacuum trucks are being deployed strategically throughout the city."  The Florida Highway Patrol has closed several exits on Interstate 95 in Fort Lauderdale, the city's fire department said. In Coral Gables in Miami-Dade County, officials are working on two water main breaks, according to the Coral Gables Police Department. Some roads in the city are shut down due to the flooding, while others have limited travel, police said, noting residents should give themselves extra time to commute to work. The Broward Sheriff's Office said in a statement Wednesday it is "being inundated with non-emergency 911 calls regarding the inclement weather" and asks residents to use 911 only for "true emergencies," also telling residents to avoid driving and to call a tow truck company if a vehicle is stranded and not in an emergency.  Some local services are shuttering Thursday. The Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport is closed due to ongoing flooding in the vicinity and will reopen at noon, according to an update from the airport. The airport's departure level reopened to allow people to exit the area, the airport said early Thursday morning.  The Brightline train service has been temporarily suspended between Miami and Fort Lauderdale, the service said on social media.  Additionally, Broward County Public Schools announced the district will be closed Thursday.  "No city could have planned for this," Trantalis said.  Trantalis says he has spoken to the White House and Senator Marco Rubio about the situation. The mayor said Gov. "DeSantis has not yet called but I'm sure he is very interested in what's going on here."  Trapped by floodwaters Mandi-Lynn Guertin flew into Fort Lauderdale with her friends for a three-day country music festival that starts Friday. The group flew in from Connecticut and had never experienced weather like this, Guertin told CNN. The car they rented got stuck in about 3 feet of water, died and water quickly filled the inside, so they had to leave it on the side of the road.  "We currently can't leave our Airbnb because the flood waters are too high and no Ubers will come out to get us," Guertin said. Guertin and her friends work in emergency services back home but Wednesday night, the quick nature of the flooding really scared them, she said. "Southern hospitality and helping your 'neighbors' is truly a thing down here and I could not be more thankful today," she wrote on Facebook. "So many strangers did so much for us tonight." For now, the group plans to wait it out at their Airbnb, without much of a choice and hope that enough water recedes so they can attend the music festival tomorrow, which has not been canceled yet. Rock The Ocean's Tortuga Music Festival, the oceanside festival, will "move forward" as planned, despite flood conditions in the city, according to event organizers. Dawn Grayson lives 20 minutes from Fort Lauderdale -- Hollywood International Airport and also got stuck on her way home Wednesday when torrential rain flooded the airport and surrounding roads.  Grayson was stuck in her car for several hours while she waited for flood waters to subside, she told CNN. "The parking garages were flooding, and vehicles got stuck," Grayson said. "We were stuck in our vehicle for 5 hours on the terminal road."

Title: The fire at an Indiana plastics recycling plant is close to being extinguished as residents wonder what's now in the air
Content: After firefighters spent two days battling an inferno fueled by plastics in eastern Indiana, it may be 99% extinguished by Thursday evening or Friday morning, officials said.  But the blaze at a Richmond recycling plant has reignited old frustrations over safety hazards at the facility and sparked new fears among residents about the future of their health. About 2,000 people living within a half-mile radius of the plant are still under evacuation orders Thursday, two days after the fire started. And for the second straight day, Richmond public schools are closed. "If you are downwind of the area, stay inside, close your windows, and turn off air conditioning," Richmond city officials warned. The fire was 90% out as of Thursday afternoon, Richmond Fire Department Chief Tim Brown said at a news conference. Firefighters are now going through the "hot zone" in the building and applying foam to extinguish the fire, Brown added. The US Environmental Protection Agency had not detected any toxic compounds as of Wednesday morning and is expected to release updated results Thursday. But the state fire marshal has already said the smoke plumes were "definitely toxic." Due to very little wind, "residents may notice that the smoke from the fire has settled more in and around the city and in areas that had not previously had issues," the Wayne County Emergency Management Agency said Thursday morning.  The EPA has been monitoring air quality at 15 locations around the site for the possibility of toxic chemicals from the incinerated plastics.  The billowing black smoke stirred memories of the recent toxic train wreck in East Palestine, Ohio. High levels of some chemicals from that disaster could pose long-term risks, researchers have said. As the black smoke spreads, so do health concerns Corey McConnell's family fled their home in the evacuation zone Tuesday night. He could already smell fumes and saw exhausted firefighters battling the blaze. "It's really unbelievable," McConnell told CNN. "Makes me worry about the health of my family, not just today but in the future as well. Who knows how long this could be in the air for?" Resident Wendy Snyder evacuated to a Red Cross emergency shelter but briefly returned home to grab a few belongings, she told CNN affiliate WHIO. That's when she noticed the stench of burning plastic. "There is a stink in the air when you go outside on our porch," Snyder said. "In fact, it burned my throat because (we) weren't wearing a mask." The primary health concern to residents is particulate matter -- fine particles found in smoke -- that could cause respiratory problems if inhaled, said Christine Stinson, executive director of the Wayne County Health Department. N95 masks could protect against the particles, but people should leave an area if they see or smell smoke or experience symptoms, Stinson said.  Due to the age of the building, asbestos -- a naturally occurring but very toxic substance once widely used for insulation -- is another possible concern. The EPA was evaluating the area, including school grounds, for potential fire debris that might contain asbestos, it said Wednesday night. And while the EPA's air quality tests had found no signs of toxic chemicals such as styrene or benzene as of mid-Wednesday morning, testing continues as more smoke settles. Such chemicals could increase the risk of cancer if someone is exposed to a high concentration for a prolonged period of time, said Richard Peltier, associate professor of environmental health sciences at the University of Massachusetts-Amherst. "We know that it is very common that a large range of chemicals are formed whenever plastic materials are burned, including styrene, benzene, and a wide number of polyaromatic hydrocarbons -- all of these are strong carcinogens, and it's important for people to avoid exposures," Peltier said. Short-term exposure could also cause symptoms, such as dizziness, nausea, coughing, headache and fatigue. "Asthma is regularly triggered by these types of complicated exposures so if you have asthma, it's really important to be extra careful," Peltier said. It's not clear when evacuated residents will be allowed to return home, Richmond officials said. Fire officials expect the smoldering site to burn for several days. City officials blame plant owner for the fire While it's not yet clear what sparked the recycling plant inferno, local leaders have shared concerns since at least 2019 that the facility was riddled with fire hazards and building code violations, records show.  "We knew it wasn't a matter of if, it was a matter of when this was going to happen," the fire chief said. In 2019, the city's Unsafe Building Commission found that the "cumulative effect of the code violations present" rendered "the premises unsafe, substandard, or a danger to the health and safety on the public," according to meeting minutes obtained by CNN.  During a commission hearing, the plant's owner, Seth Smith, admitted one of the buildings on the property had no fire extinguishing system, the records show. CNN has reached out to Smith, and the attorney who previously represented him in a related lawsuit declined to comment. Richmond officials "were aware that what was operating here was a fire hazard," Mayor Dave Snow said Wednesday, accusing the plant's owner of ignoring a city order to clean up the property. The fire began in a semitrailer loaded with plastics, then spread to surrounding piles of recyclables before eventually reaching the building, which was "completely full from floor to ceiling and from wall to wall," Brown, fire chief, said. When firefighters arrived, he said, they had difficulty reaching the buildings because access roads were blocked by piles of plastic.  "Everything that's ensued here -- the fire, the damages, the risk that our first responders have taken and the risk these citizens are under -- are the responsibility of that negligent business owner," Snow said.  After Smith was ordered by the city building commission to repair or demolish and vacate his properties in 2019, the plant owner and his company petitioned a court to review the order.  An Indiana circuit court judge ruled in favor of the city in March 2020. The court found in part Smith's properties "constitute a fire hazard; are a hazard to public health; constitute a nuisance; and are dangerous to people or property because of violations of statute and City Ordinance concerning building condition and maintenance." The city last year seized two of the three land parcels the recycling plant sits on after Smith failed to pay property taxes.  It's unclear what steps the city took to remedy the site since the seizure and whether it took any steps before 2022 to enforce its orders requiring Smith to repair or demolish and vacate the properties. Smith was contacted by an investigator Tuesday night, the mayor said. While firefighters try to snuff out the blaze, they face another challenge: trying not to destroy potential evidence that might help determine the cause, Brown said.  Officials probably won't be able to identify the cause of the blaze until after the fire is extinguished and investigators can safely enter the plant, the state fire marshal's office said.   Any legal liability against the plant owner will be handled after the cleanup process, City Attorney Andrew J. Sickmann said at a Thursday news conference. "Whether or not there can be potential criminal liability would be a question for law enforcement and prosecutors," Sickmann said. The only operation running out of the building before the fire was moving materials out and shipping them overseas as ordered by officials, Sickmann said. "It's his mess, it's been shown again and again it's his mess," Snow, the mayor, said of the owner. "Everything that's ensued here remains his responsibility." Snow added that they are tracking all costs of the incident in case of potential litigation.

Title: Watch: Suspect who leaked classified documents arrested
Content: Isa Soares speaks with CNN national security analysts and reporters about 21-year-old Jack Teixeira, a member of the Massachusetts Air National Guard, who has been arrested in connection with the leaking of classified documents.

Title: A man with schizophrenia died after being kept naked and malnourished in solitary confinement at an Indiana jail for nearly 3 weeks, lawsuit says
Content: An Indiana man with a history of schizophrenia died in the summer of 2021 due to organ failure following nearly three weeks in solitary confinement at a Jackson County jail, according to a newly filed lawsuit.   The lawsuit says jailers placed Joshua McLemore, 29, in a windowless, padded isolation cell, where he remained "confined, naked, alone, and in a constant state of psychosis for the next 20 days." The suit, filed on behalf of McLemore's estate, is brought against Jackson County and its sheriff Rick Meyer, three jail employees, a doctor who oversaw clinical issues and procedures for the county and jail, and the company that provides health care services at the facility, Advanced Correctional Healthcare.  McLemore's cause of death was "multiple organ failure due to refusal to eat or drink with altered mental status due to untreated schizophrenia," according to a coroner's report provided by his attorney. A history of methamphetamine withdrawal was also noted as a contributing factor.  McLemore's death was the result of "multiple acts of indifference, as well as systemic and unconstitutional deficiencies" in the county's policies, practices and training programs, says the suit filed Wednesday in the US District Court for the Southern District of Indiana.  Additionally, it says the jail did not sufficiently supervise or train its staff on how to handle serious medical or mental health care issues and accuses Advanced Correctional Healthcare of having insufficient training and inadequate staffing. Advanced Correctional Healthcare told CNN in a statement that it was not allowed to disclose patient information, but that it "is proud to have a 95% client retention rate. ACH has a reputation for solving problems by doing the right thing the first time. In the last year, at least 52 patient lives have been saved." CNN has reached out to the Jackson County Sheriff's Office for comment. "Josh McLemore wasn't a criminal," Hank Balson, an attorney representing McLemore's estate, told CNN in a statement. "He was mentally ill and in crisis. He was out of touch with reality and needed help. This is glaringly obvious to anyone who watches the videos of him in his isolation cell." According to the lawsuit, McLemore struggled with diagnosed schizophrenia and substance abuse and was in the midst of an "acute mental health crisis." He was taken to the emergency room to be evaluated after his apartment manager found him in his apartment, naked, confused, and disoriented.   McLemore was arrested for pulling a nurse's hair while in the emergency room, placed in handcuffs and leg shackles, and carried out of the hospital, naked except for his underwear, according to Balson. He was charged with battery against a public official and criminal mischief damage and taken to the Jackson County Jail on July 20, 2021, according to court documents.  Upon arriving at the jail, McLemore was taken to the padded isolation cell and remained there "almost continuously" until his death weeks later, the suit says. He was only taken from the cell four times, it said, mainly when jail employees would strap him to a chair and put him under a shower or clean his cell.  Though food was delivered to McLemore's cell door two or three times a day, he didn't retrieve the food or would dump some or all of it on the floor of his cell, which was littered with urine, feces, and torn food containers, according to the suit. While in the cell, McLemore lost nearly 45 pounds.  Guards kept the bathroom adjoining the cell locked for most of the time he was confined, the suit says. Surveillance video included in the lawsuit shows McLemore naked in a cell that appears to have substances smeared on the walls and floor. "By the time staff finally sent Josh to the hospital, his condition was so dire that the local hospital did not have the clinical resources to treat him and he had to be airlifted to a larger hospital in Cincinnati, where he died two days later," the lawsuit said. A 2022 investigation by the Jackson County Prosecuting Attorney found that no crimes were committed by jail employees in relation to McLemore's death, according to CNN affiliate WDRB. The lawsuit brings a claim for the violation of McLemore's 14th Amendment rights, accusing all defendants of "causing him unnecessary pain and suffering and, ultimately, an avoidable death." It is seeking compensatory and punitive damages.

Title: Man with schizophrenia dies after weeks in isolation according to lawsuit
Content: A lawsuit has been filed by the estate of Joshua McLemore, whose lawyers say he was experiencing a mental health crisis when he was placed in a windowless isolation cell where he remained naked and confined for the next 20 days before he died.

Title: Louisville mass shooting victim had just moved to city two weeks earlier for new bank job
Content: The daughter of Juliana Farmer, one of the five victims of the mass shooting at a bank in Louisville, Kentucky, said Wednesday night her mother had just moved to Louisville two weeks prior for a new job.  "This monster took away my mother, and I'm hurt because my mother moved here to help me, a single mom with four kids. I only got two weeks with her here in Louisville ... a city she knew nothing about," Alia Chambers told CNN. "I'm heartbroken. I hated him. I hated him but I forgive him because my mama is in a better place." Farmer moved to Louisville from Henderson, Kentucky, and was thrilled to begin her role with Old National Bank as a loan officer. "My mom went from working at 19 years old at Kmart to sitting with executives at a bank. I'm gonna fulfill my mama's dream. Either I'm going back to nursing school or I'm gonna ask them, can I take over her position at that bank," she said. "She was so excited about that job. She was happy." Farmer had three adult children and four grandsons, Chambers said.  The day before she was killed, she found out her son, J'Yeon Chambers, was expecting a baby girl, he told CNN. The baby is due in September, the same month his mother was born. "And so it's just crazy how she gets taken the day after we reveal that we're having the baby. So my child is going to be her basically all over again," her son said. "She gave us the name that she always wanted a girl to be named and we're going to stick with it." The new details come as CNN has learned more about the victims and wounded in Monday's workplace mass shooting, including the survival of a woman who was seated between two people who were killed. Old National Bank employee Connor Sturgeon, 25, opened fire with an AR15-style rifle in an office conference room and killed five colleagues before he was fatally shot by a responding officer. Farmer, Joshua Barrick, Tommy Elliott, Deana Eckert and James Tutt were shot and killed, police said.  Of the eight people who were wounded, a 26-year-old police officer remains in critical condition after being shot in the head, requiring brain surgery. Woman who was seated between two victims released from hospital One woman who was shot but survived was seated between Farmer and Elliott when the attack began, according to the father of her children, Rex Minrath. Dana Mitchell, an employee at the bank, has returned home from the hospital and is recovering, Minrath told CNN in a phone interview Thursday. She is expected to have surgery in the coming weeks to remove "the rest of the bullet," he said.  "Dana was in the conference room between Tommy and Juliana. She sat between those two," Minrath told CNN. "And then when they hit the ground, they were all on the ground together. She is fortunate because both of them weren't so lucky." Mitchell's son, Ross Minrath, posted a series of images and updates about his mother's condition on his Facebook page this week. "After positive results from blood work and her being an all around badass, my Mom was released from the hospital today," he wrote on Tuesday night. "She is very sore but doing well. Her phone has been at the bank and hopes to start reaching out herself tomorrow." In one Facebook post, he said the gunshot bruised her lung and that doctors were able to clean the wound on her back. His mother, he added, "is the toughest I've ever known." He thanked those who had reached out to the family with well wishes and asked for people to continue to send prayers for his mother. In addition, the first person who was shot inside the bank survived, a city official told CNN. In the shooter's Instagram livestream of the attack, which has since been taken down, the female bank worker said "good morning" before the gunman warned her, "You need to get out of here," according to an official familiar with the video. The woman had her back to the gunman as he struggled to get the safety off and load his AR15-style weapon properly. He then shot her in the back, an official previously told CNN. Governor says he's 'empty' after friend's death At a vigil Wednesday, scores of residents and officials gathered Wednesday evening to mourn publicly the employees gunned down at their workplace by a coworker.
